column14: Roving Surveys of Quesnel Watershed — Pacific Salmon Treaty
column15: Task Description:1.The Organization will work jointly with DFO conducting live counts, dead pitch/carcass recovery, and collecting samples.  Work includes rafting (Horsefly), lake boat travel on Quesnel Lake, jet boating on Mitchell River, and stream walks.  2.This work will be conducted in approximately 4 weeks; 7 days a week from September 16 to October 11, 2019. First week of work will include a couple days of orientation. Orientation may occur at the Quesnel Lake Research station in Likely, rather than at Horsefly. 3.Two NSTC Technicians will be part of the regular roving crew covering the Quesnel system watershed.  Depending on daily work location, crew will report for work at 8am at either the Horsefly Spawning Channel or at DFO’s rented accommodation (about 10 minutes towards Elysha Resort from the Horsefly Spawning Channel). 4.Technicians would need to supply their own Personal Protective Equipment (e.g., waders, field vests, life jackets, etc.). DFO can provide pews and machetes, if needed, as well as any other fish sampling gear. 5.
column70: Paper, followed by entry into computer

column14: Quesnel Sockeye Sampling and Enumeration Support — Pacific Salmon Treaty
column15: Task Description: 1.The Organization will work jointly with DFO conducting live counts, dead pitch/carcass recovery, and collecting samples. Work includes rafting (Horsefly), lake boat travel on Quesnel Lake, jet boating on Mitchell River, and stream walks. 2.The Organization will work jointly with DFO conducting the necessary field work to inform an estimate of the total sockeye escapement and effective spawning population by individual to the Quesnel system. Activities include measuring live and dead sockeye abundance, collecting biological samples (tissue, scales and otoliths) from spawning grounds, recording sex ratios and spawning success, habitat monitoring (water levels and temperature), spawner distribution within streams, and pre-spawn mortality in the approach and terminal spawning areas. 3.This work is planned to be conducted over 3 weeks; 7 days a week, 0800-1600 hours, from September 14 to October 4, 2020. However, actual scheduling of work can vary dependent on in-season abundance reports in the watershed. 4.NSTC fisheries technicians will be given a combination of in-person and online training at the start of the contract period to ensure all field staff are current with health and safety awareness and procedures for field operations. DFO Fisheries Technicians will provide expertise and on-the-ground training in sample collection procedures.5. NSTC will provide two NSTC fisheries technicians with the necessary equipment and gear to conduct the creek surveys and sample collection. A list of necessary gear will be provided to NSTC in advance of the project. NSTC will also supply their technicians with a means of transportation to and from the pre-determined work start site in Horsefly, BC.
column70: Paper, followed by entry into computer

column15: Task Description:1.The Organization will install and maintain two SONAR units (one on each bank) with deflection fences at the Quesnel Research facility sonar site on the Quesnel River from approximately September 28 to November 6, 2020. 2.The Organization will download data and conduct immediate counts of the first 20 minutes of each hour. Further counts will be conducted as time allows.3.The Organization will provide bi-weekly data to DFO, using an Excel spreadsheet provided by DFO. DFO will provide training on how to complete the Excel spreadsheet and the requirements for in-season reporting.
column70: Paper, followed by entry into computer

column15: Juvenile Chinook in Bedwell Sound and Moyeha River will be bio-sampled and tagged to collect data for use in Genetic Stock identification. Additional juvenile trapping includes seining in the Bedwell River Estuary and the Bedwell Sound once a week, as well as employing beach seines.

column15: The Organization will survey, by foot, specific coho salmon spawning locations in the Sakinaw Lake watershed. Surveys will aid in establishing spawning timing, fish distribution and numbers of spawners in the watershed. Activities will occur from mid-November to December 31, 2019. Surveys may extend into January 2020 if spawning extends that late. Biological samples from spawned carcasses will be collected to determine the average lengths, age structure, pre-spawn mortality incidence and genetic baseline information. Work activities will include the following:   1. Conduct stream walks in the creek tributaries to Sakinaw Lake. The target creeks are; Sakinaw Lake outlet canal, Mixal, Haskins, Boat Ramp Lower Ruby, Prospector and Kokomo Creeks. Foot surveys will be conducted at a minimum of once per week to identify the timing of spawners entering and the numbers of spawning coho in each creek. The creeks will be accessed by truck and boat. For each creek surveyed, a Stream Inspection Log (SIL) will be filled out.    2.  Carcass recovery/sampling by locating spawned out fish and sampling on the grounds. When carcasses are located, biosample each carcass as instructed by DFO Stock Assessment staff, and complete biosampling data sheets, scale books and Whatman sheets for DNA analyses, and otoliths.
column70: Paper, followed by entry into computer

column14: Investigation of Adult Coho Use in Key Tributaries of the Sakinaw Lake Watershed

Biological samples from spawned carcasses will also be collected to determine average lengths, age structure, genetic baseline information, and so on.
column70: Paper, followed by entry into computer

column15:
Nanaimo River Assessment - carry out several projects and attend meetings in support of the Nanaimo Spring run chinook Recovery Potential Assessment (RPA). The work activities include the following:
1. Upper Nanaimo River swim surveys and habitat assessment activities: Weekly swim surveys in the upper Nanaimo River beginning in September. Surveys will run from 4 to 6 weeks, dependent on spawn timing and associated carcass recovery. Additional tasks will include habitat assessment work including assistance with water quality and habitat survey equipment installation and use.   2. Lower Nanaimo River chum enumeration data review: review of video data from a Dual Identification Sonar (DIDSON) to estimate chum salmon abundance on the Nanaimo River. Data review will take place full-time for ~7 weeks, beginning in October.    3.  Meeting attendance:  will attend meetings for the Risk Assessment Management workshop and RPA Canadian Science Advisory Secretariat (CSAS) review.  4.  Nanaino River Estuary marine mammal surveys: survey of pinnipeds and other marine mammals (i.e. otters and minks) in the Nanaimo River Estuary from October to March. Up to 20 surveys will be conducted by power boat with a minimum of two persons (surveyor + driver).
column70: Paper, followed by entry into computer

column15: To carry out: (1) Upper Nanaimo River swim surveys and habitat assessment; (2) Lower Nanaimo River chum enumeration data review (video data from a DIDSON to estimate chum abundance); (3) attendance of meetings for RPA management workshop and RPA CSAS review; and (4) Nanaimo River Estuary marine mammal surveys by boat.
